The '''Gaming and Wagering Commission of Western Australia''' is the regulatory authority responsible for overseeing all forms of gambling within Western Australia. It is unique among Australian states for its prohibition of poker machines in pubs and clubs, allowing them only in the casino at Crown Perth. The Commission also regulates TAB operations and the racing industry, ensuring compliance with state legislation and maintaining the integrity of gambling activities.

== Regulatory Functions ==
The Gaming and Wagering Commission of Western Australia has several key responsibilities:

* Regulation of casino gaming, including the oversight of gaming machines, which are only permitted at Crown Perth.
* Management and regulation of the Totalisator Agency Board (TAB) and racing activities.
* Ensuring compliance with minimum return to player (RTP) requirements, which are set at a minimum of 90% for casino gaming machines.

== Unique Approach ==
Western Australia is distinct in its approach to gambling regulation, particularly with its ban on poker machines in pubs and clubs. This policy is aimed at reducing the potential for gambling-related harm in the community.

== Regulation of Crown Perth ==
Crown Perth is the only venue in Western Australia where casino gaming machines are permitted. The Gaming and Wagering Commission is responsible for ensuring that Crown Perth operates within the legal framework and adheres to the required standards of fairness and transparency.

== TAB and Racing Regulation ==
The Commission also oversees the operations of the TAB and the racing industry in Western Australia. This includes the regulation of betting activities and ensuring that these operations are conducted fairly and responsibly.

== Minimum RTP Requirements ==
The minimum return to player (RTP) for casino gaming machines in Western Australia is set at 90%. This ensures that a fair proportion of the money wagered is returned to players over time, maintaining a balance between profitability and player protection.
